articles.title: S. Migaľ: Slovakia has used up 1.5 billion euros from EU funds and has met the N 3 rule
articles.summary: Minister of Investments of the Slovak Republic Samuel Migaľ announced that Slovakia has used up 1.5 billion euros of EU funds and has met the N+3 rule.
articles.content:
Minister of Investments of the Slovak Republic Samuel Migaľ announced that Slovakia has used up 1.5 billion euros of EU funds and has met the N+3 rule.

Bratislava – Slovakia has drawn 1.5 billion euros from EU funds and at the same time, as of November 30 of this year, has also fulfilled the commitments of the N+3 mechanism. The mechanism stipulates that financial resources allocated to a state for a specific year must be spent and properly accounted for by the end of the third calendar year after their allocation. The Communication Department of the Ministry of Investments, Regional Development and Informatization (MIRRI) of the Slovak Republic informed about this on Wednesday, reports TASR.

“We managed to significantly speed up the drawing of European money already in 2025, when we had the obligation to draw 1.5 billion euros. The new leadership of the ministry set up processes so that EU money ends up in real projects as quickly as possible and brings concrete help to the regions. Since we took office, we have increased the drawing from the original not quite six percent to the current 12.3%, which is more than a twofold increase and brings visible results,” said Minister Samuel Migaľ (independent).

He recalled that previous governments announced the first calls in the Slovakia Programme only in 2023, and the first delegation agreements between MIRRI and intermediary bodies were signed only in the middle of the same year. According to Migaľ, this caused time delays, because projects must not only be approved and implemented, but subsequently also reimbursed within the set deadlines.

Slovakia has doubled the drawing of EU funds this year

The minister added that this year the drawing of EU funds has doubled; currently 6.32 billion euros are contractually tied up in projects, that is, more than half of the allocation. MIRRI also wants to continue supporting projects that bring visible benefits to the regions.

“This approach is also linked to the success in averting the threat of decommitment for 2026. Thanks to the revision of the Slovakia Programme, through which we are responding to the new EU priorities within the Modernised Cohesion Policy, it was possible to save approximately 750 million euros. After approval by the Monitoring Committee and the European Commission, this step will ensure that the funds remain in Slovakia and we will gain one extra year for their effective use,” added the investment department. (December 3)

The impact is broad, affecting public projects and regional growth, with clear details on improved fund drawing rates and policy adjustments to prevent fund loss.
articles.personality_title: Slovakia successfully uses 1.5 billion euros of EU funds on time
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Slovakia receives money from the European Union (EU) to support projects that help develop regions and improve public services. Countries must spend this money within a set deadline called the N+3 rule, which means funds given in one year must be used properly within three years.

**What happened** – The Slovak Ministry of Investments announced that Slovakia has spent 1.5 billion euros from EU funds and met the N+3 rule deadline by November 30, 2023. This is a big improvement compared to previous years, as the ministry increased the speed of spending from about 6% to 12.3% of the funds. Slovakia also has 6.32 billion euros tied to ongoing projects, showing strong progress in using the total available money.

**Impact** – Meeting the N+3 rule on time means Slovakia avoids losing important EU money that supports development projects. The faster spending helps regions get benefits sooner, like better infrastructure or services. The ministry's work also prevented the loss of around 750 million euros by adjusting plans to match new EU priorities, giving Slovakia an extra year to use the funds.

**What's next step** – The ministry will continue to support projects that bring clear improvements to regions. After final approvals, Slovakia will have more time to use the remaining funds effectively, which could lead to more development and stronger local communities.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Slovakia has improved how it uses EU funds, spending 1.5 billion euros on time and securing more money for future regional projects.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Slovaquie utilise avec succès 1,5 milliard d'euros de fonds européens dans les délais
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Slovaquie reçoit de l'argent de l'Union européenne (UE) pour soutenir des projets qui développent les régions et améliorent les services publics. Les pays doivent dépenser cet argent dans un délai fixé appelé règle N+3, ce qui signifie que les fonds donnés une année doivent être utilisés correctement dans les trois ans.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le ministère slovaque des Investissements a annoncé que la Slovaquie a dépensé 1,5 milliard d'euros de fonds européens et respecté le délai de la règle N+3 au 30 novembre 2023. Cela représente une nette amélioration par rapport aux années précédentes, car le ministère a accéléré la dépense des fonds de 6 % à 12,3 %. La Slovaquie a aussi 6,32 milliards d'euros engagés dans des projets en cours, montrant un bon progrès dans l'utilisation de l'argent disponible.

**Impact** – Respecter la règle N+3 à temps signifie que la Slovaquie évite de perdre des fonds européens importants qui soutiennent les projets de développement. Une dépense plus rapide permet aux régions de bénéficier plus tôt d'améliorations comme de meilleures infrastructures ou services. Le ministère a aussi évité la perte d'environ 750 millions d'euros en ajustant les plans selon les nouvelles priorités de l'UE, ce qui donne une année supplémentaire pour utiliser les fonds.

**Prochaine étape** – Le ministère continuera à soutenir des projets qui apportent des améliorations visibles aux régions. Après les dernières approbations, la Slovaquie aura plus de temps pour utiliser efficacement les fonds restants, ce qui pourrait entraîner plus de développement et des communautés locales renforcées.

**En une phrase** – La Slovaquie a amélioré l'utilisation de ses fonds européens, dépensant 1,5 milliard d'euros dans les délais et garantissant plus d'argent pour les projets régionaux à venir.
articles.personality_title_es: Eslovaquia utiliza con éxito 1.5 mil millones de euros de fondos de la UE a tiempo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Eslovaquia recibe dinero de la Unión Europea (UE) para apoyar proyectos que desarrollan regiones y mejoran servicios públicos. Los países deben gastar este dinero dentro de un plazo llamado regla N+3, que significa que los fondos dados en un año deben usarse correctamente dentro de tres años.

**Qué pasó** – El Ministerio de Inversiones de Eslovaquia anunció que el país ha gastado 1.5 mil millones de euros de fondos de la UE y cumplió con el plazo de la regla N+3 al 30 de noviembre de 2023. Esto es una gran mejora en comparación con años anteriores, ya que el ministerio aumentó la velocidad de gasto del 6 % al 12.3 %. Además, 6.32 mil millones de euros están comprometidos en proyectos en curso, mostrando un fuerte progreso en el uso del dinero disponible.

**Impacto** – Cumplir la regla N+3 a tiempo significa que Eslovaquia evita perder dinero importante de la UE que apoya proyectos de desarrollo. Gastar más rápido ayuda a que las regiones reciban beneficios antes, como mejores infraestructuras o servicios. El ministerio también evitó la pérdida de unos 750 millones de euros al ajustar los planes para alinearse con las nuevas prioridades de la UE, ganando un año extra para usar los fondos.

**Próximo paso** – El ministerio seguirá apoyando proyectos que traigan mejoras claras a las regiones. Tras las aprobaciones finales, Eslovaquia tendrá más tiempo para usar los fondos restantes de forma efectiva, lo que podría llevar a más desarrollo y comunidades locales más fuertes.

**Una frase clave** – Eslovaquia ha mejorado su uso de los fondos de la UE, gastando 1.5 mil millones de euros a tiempo y asegurando más dinero para futuros proyectos regionales.
